Context-Aware Online Client Selection for Hierarchical Federated Learning

Zhe Qu, Rui Duan, Lixing Chen, Jie Xu,  Zhuo Lu,  and Yao Liu Z. Qu, R. Duan and Z. Lu are with the Department of Electrical Engineering, University of South Florida, Tampa, FL, 33620 USA. E-mail: {zhequ, ruiduan, zhuolu}@usf.edu.L. Chen is with the Institute of Cyber Science and Technology, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, Shanghai, 200240 China. E-mail:lxchen@sjtu.edu.cn.J. Xu is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Miami, Coral Gables, 33146 USA. E-mail: jiexu@miami.edu.Y. Liu is with the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of South Florida, Tampa, 33620 USA. E-mail: yliu@cse.usf.edu.
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) has been considered as an appealing framework to tackle data privacy issues of mobile devices compared to conventional Machine Learning (ML). Using Edge Servers (ESs) as intermediaries to perform model aggregation in proximity can reduce the transmission overhead, and it enables great potentials in low-latency FL, where the hierarchical architecture of FL (HFL) has been attracted more attention. Designing a proper client selection policy can significantly improve training performance, and it has been extensively used in FL studies. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are no studies focusing on HFL. In addition, client selection for HFL faces more challenges than conventional FL, e.g., the time-varying connection of client-ES pairs and the limited budget of the Network Operator (NO). In this paper, we investigate a client selection problem for HFL, where the NO learns the number of successful participating clients to improve the training performance (i.e., select as many clients in each round) as well as under the limited budget on each ES. An online policy, called Context-aware Online Client Selection (COCS), is developed based on Contextual Combinatorial Multi-Armed Bandit (CC-MAB). COCS observes the side-information (context) of local computing and transmission of client-ES pairs and makes client selection decisions to maximize NO’s utility given a limited budget. Theoretically, COCS achieves a sublinear regret compared to an Oracle policy on both strongly convex and non-convex HFL. Simulation results also support the efficiency of the proposed COCS policy on real-world datasets.

I Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) [1, 2, 3, 4] has become an attractive ML framework to address the growing concerns of transmitting private data from distributed clients (e.g., mobile devices) to a central cloud server by leveraging the ever-increasing storage and computing capabilities of the client devices. In each FL round, clients train local models using their local data and the cloud server aggregates local model updates to form a global model. Because only local model information is exchanged in FL rather than the local data, FL preserves the data privacy of the clients and hence has found applications in a wide range of problems, such as next-word prediction [5] and image classification [6].

A main bottleneck that limits the performance of FL is the delay variability among individual clients due to their local training and model data transfer via the wireless network. In standard FL, the cloud server has to wait until receiving the training updates from all the clients before processing any next step. Therefore, straggler clients who have unfavorable wireless links or low computation capabilities may dramatically slow down the whole FL process [7, 8]. This is the so-called “straggler effect”. Various approaches have been proposed to mitigate the “straggler effect”. For example, model quantization [9, 10] and gradient sparsification [11] schemes aim to directly reduce the transferred data size and the model training complexity, thereby reducing all clients’ training and transmission delay. Asynchronous FL [12, 13] allows clients to train and upload training data in an asynchronous manner, and hence the cloud server does not have to wait for the slow clients to process the next step. Another mainstream and proven effective approach to address the straggler problem is client selection, which reduces the probability of straggler clients participating in FL by judiciously selecting clients in every FL round. In this paper, we aim to improve the FL performance along the lines of client selection in the context of hierarchical FL (HFL), which is a hierarchical architecture of FL that significantly reduces the communication overhead between the cloud server and the clients.

The key idea of HFL is the introduction of multiple edge servers which reside between the single cloud server and the large number of clients. Instead of communicating directly to the cloud server, the clients only send their local training updates to the nearby edge servers, each of which performs an intermediate model aggregation. These aggregated models are further sent to the cloud server for the global aggregation. HFL significantly reduces the communication burden on the network and has been shown to achieve a faster convergence speed than the conventional FL architecture both theoretically [14, 15] and empirically [16]. Although several learning algorithms have been designed for HFL, simplifying assumptions have been made that all clients participate in each round of model parameter aggregation and hence, the “straggler effect” in HFL has not been specifically addressed. However, it is not straightforward to apply existing client selection solutions to HFL due to several unique challenges that HFL faces. Firstly, since the service area of an ES is much more restricted than Cloud Server (CS) and contains overlapping areas, the accessible clients of each ES are time-varying. This time-varying characteristic makes the client behavior of opportunistic communication more complicated, and Network Operator (NO) must carefully select the client to the corresponding ES in the overlapping area. Secondly, since the advantage of HFL is to deal with the straggler problem, how to design an efficient client selection policy is more important than traditional FL. Thirdly, the client selection decision needs to be determined based on many uncertainties in the HFL network conditions, e.g., the traffic pattern of client-ES pair and available computation resources of clients, which affect training performance in previously unknown ways. Therefore, a learning-based client selection policy is preferred to a solely optimization-based policy.

In this paper, we investigate the client selection problem for HFL and propose a new learning-based policy, called Context-aware Online Client Selection (COCS). COCS is developed based on a novel Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB) framework called Contextual Combinatorial MAB (CC-MAB) [17, 18, 19]. COCS is contextual because it allows clients to use their computational information, e.g., available computation resources, and the client-ES pairs transmission information, e.g., bandwidth and distance. COCS is combinatorial because NO selects a subset of client-ES pairs and attempts to maximize the training utilities (i.e., select as many as clients in each round) by optimizing the client selection decision. To the best of our knowledge, COCS policy is the first client selection decision for HFL. In summary, we highlight the contributions of this paper as follows:

1) We formulate a client selection problem for HFL, where NO needs to select clients to ESs clients to process the local training in order to make more clients to be received by ESs before deadline under limited budget. To improve the convergence speed for HFL, client selection decision has a three-fold problem: (i) estimate the local model updates successfully received by ESs with cold-starts, (ii) decide whether a client should be selected to a certain ES due to time-varying connection conditions, and (iii) optimize how to pay computation resources on clients to maximize the utility under limited budgets.

2) Due to the a priori uncertain knowledge of participated clients, the client selection problem is formulated as a CC-MAB problem. An online learning policy called Context-aware Online Client Selection (COCS) is developed, which leverages the contextual information such as downloading channel state and local computing time over aggregation round for making a decision. For the strongly convex HFL, we analyze the utility loss of COCS, termed regret, compared to the Oracle solution that knows the exacted information of participated clients. A sublinear regret bound is derived for the proposed COCS policy, which implies that COCS can produce asymptotically optimal client selection decisions for HFL.

3) For non-convex HFL, the utility function of the convergence speed is quadratically related to the number of participated clients. By assuming that the information of each client-ES pair is perfectly known by NO, we show that the client selection problem is a submodular maximization problem with M𝑀M knapsack and one matroid constraints, where M𝑀M is the number of ESs. We use the Fast Lazy Greedy (FLGreedy) algorithm [20] to approximate the optimal solution with a performance guarantee. To this end, the analysis shows that the COCS policy also achieves a sublinear regret.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II overviews the related works. The system model and client selection problem of HFL are presented in Section III. We design the Context-aware Online Client Selection (COCS) policy for strongly convex HFL and provide an analytical performance guarantee in Section IV. Section V presents the COCS policy for non-convex HFL, which is applied by the approximated oracle solutions. Simulation results are shown in Section VI, followed by the conclusion in Section VII.

II Related Work

We provide a brief literature review that includes three main lines of work: client selection for FL, HFL, and the MAB problems for FL.

Due to the heterogeneous clients and limited resources of wireless FL networks, client selection can significantly improve the performance of FL in terms of convergence speed and training latency. For example, [21] designs a deep reinforcement learning algorithm (the local model updates and the global model are considered as states) to select clients. [22] uses gradient information to select clients. If the inner product between the client’s local and global gradient is negative, it will be excluded. In [23], they develop a system model to estimate the total number of aggregation rounds and design a greedy algorithm to jointly optimize client selection and bandwidth allocation throughout the training process, thereby minimizing the training latency. [24] designs a dynamic client sampling method. In the early aggregation rounds, fewer clients are selected, and more clients in later rounds. This method has been proven to improve the training loss and accuracy as well as decreasing the overall energy consumption. These client selection methods focus on the conventional FL, which is different from our consideration of HFL.

HFL has been considered to be a more practical FL framework for the current MEC system, since the hierarchical architecture makes FL communication more efficient and significantly reduces the latency [14]. Later, some studies improve the performance of HFL from different perspectives or use it in some other applications. For example, [16, 15] propose a detailed convergence analysis of HFL, showing that the convergence speed of HFL achieves a linear speedup of conventional FL. Recently, FL has attracted the more interest, especially with the rapid development of ML applications on IoT devices. [25] designs a hierarchical blockchain framework for knowledge sharing on smart vehicles, which learn the environmental data through ML methods and share the learning knowledge with others. [26] uses HFL to better adapt to personalized modeling tasks and protect private information.

The MAB problem has been extensively studied to address the key trade-off between exploration and exploitation making under uncertain environment [27], and it has been used in FL for designing the client scheduling or selection [28, 29, 30]. [28] designs a client scheduling problem and provides a MAB-based framework for FL training without knowing the wireless channel state information and the dynamic usage of local computing resources. In order to minimize the latency, [29] models fair-guaranteed client selection as a Lyapunov optimization problem and presents a policy based on CC-MAB to estimate the model transmission time. A multi-agent MAB algorithm is developed to minimize the FL training latency over wireless channels, constrained by training performance as well as each client’s differential privacy requirement in [30]. In this paper, the COCS policy is proposed to select clients for HFL. Due to the dynamic connection conditions of the client-ES pair and the limited available computing capacities of clients in each edge aggregation round, the COCS policy faces more challenges than these studies.

III System Model and Problem Formulation

III-A Preliminary of Hierarchical Federated Learning

The Network Operator (NO) leverages a typical edge-cloud architecture to offer the Federated Learning (FL) service, known as Hierarchical FL (HFL) [14, 16, 15] as in Fig. 1. Unlike the conventional FL [2, 1, 3, 4] that involves only clients and a Cloud Server (CS), HFL consists of a set of mobile devices/clients, indexed by 𝒩={1,2,…,N}𝒩12…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\dots,N\}, a set of Edge Servers (ES), indexed by ℳ={1,2,…,M}ℳ12…𝑀\mathcal{M}=\{1,2,\dots,M\} and a Cloud Server (CS). Note that the communication areas of different edge servers may be overlapped (i.e., ∑m=1MNmt≥Nsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑡𝑁\sum_{m=1}^{M}N_{m}^{t}\geq N). For each client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, it is able to communicate with a subset of ESs 𝒞nt⊆ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒞𝑡𝑛ℳ\mathcal{C}^{t}_{n}\subseteq\mathcal{M} in round t𝑡t. In particular, we assume that each client is equipped with a single antenna so that it can communicates with only one ES m∈𝒞nt𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑡m\in\mathcal{C}_{n}^{t} at a time even if it is located in the overlapped area of multiple ESs in each round. Let 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} denote the parameters of the global model. The training steps of HFL can be summarized as follows:

(i) At the beginning of round t𝑡t, each ES m𝑚m randomly selects a subset of clients 𝒔mt⊆𝒩mtsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\bm{s}_{m}^{t}\subseteq\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t} in its coverage area. Repeating the above four steps with a sufficiently large number T𝑇T of rounds, NO will achieve the global model 𝒘=𝒘T𝒘superscript𝒘𝑇\bm{w}=\bm{w}^{T} and stop the training process. HFL has been demonstrated to be able to achieve a linear speedup of convergence compared to conventional FL algorithms [16, 15].

III-B Cost of Client Selection

Since clients usually do not belong to NO, clients charge NO for the amount of requested computation resources for collecting the dataset and performing the local training to achieve the learning goal. At the beginning of each edge aggregation round, each client reveals its available computation resources yntsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡y_{n}^{t}, including CPU frequency, RAM and storage for the current round t𝑡t. NO pays cn​(ynt)subscript𝑐𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑡𝑛c_{n}(y^{t}_{n}) to the client depending on the available computation resources, where cn​(⋅)subscript𝑐𝑛⋅c_{n}(\cdot) is a non-decreasing function. Due to the limited budget B~~𝐵\tilde{B} of NO, in any edge aggregation round t𝑡t, the client selection decision of NO must satisfy the budget constraint ∑m∈ℳ∑n∈𝒔mtcn​(ynt)≤B~subscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡~𝐵\sum\nolimits_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}_{m}^{t}}c_{n}(y_{n}^{t})\leq\tilde{B}.

III-C Deadline Based HFL

In summary, an edge aggregation consists of four stages: Download Transmission (DT), Local Computation (LC), Upload Transmission (UT) and Edge Computation (EC).

In DT stage, the selected client n∈𝒔mt𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡n\in\bm{s}_{m}^{t} downloads the current edge model from the ES m𝑚m. Followed by Shannon’s equation, the channel state of DT cDT,ntsubscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡DT𝑛c^{t}_{\text{DT},n} is calculated by:

where Pntsubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑡𝑛P^{t}_{n} is the transmission power, gDT,ntsubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑡DT𝑛g^{t}_{\text{DT},n} is the downlink wireless channel gain and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power. The EC time is τEC,mt=qm/ymsubscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡EC𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚subscript𝑦𝑚\tau^{t}_{\text{EC},m}=q_{m}/y_{m}, where qmsubscript𝑞𝑚q_{m} is the edge model workload and ymsuperscript𝑦𝑚y^{m} is the process capacity of the ES m𝑚m. Since τEC,msubscript𝜏EC𝑚\tau_{\text{EC},m} is the same for all the selected clients at ES m𝑚m, the training time of client n𝑛n is defined as follows:

τnt​(ynt)=τDT,nt+τLC,nt​(ynt)+τUT,nt=aDT,ntbnt​cDT,nt+qynt+aUT,ntbnt​cUT,nt,∀n,t.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡DT𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡LC𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡UT𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎DT𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑐DT𝑛𝑡𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑎UT𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑐UT𝑛𝑡for-all𝑛𝑡\begin{split}\tau^{t}_{n}(y_{n}^{t})&=\tau^{t}_{\text{DT},n}+\tau^{t}_{\text{LC},n}(y_{n}^{t})+\tau^{t}_{\text{UT},n}\\ &=\frac{a_{\text{DT},n}^{t}}{b_{n}^{t}c_{\text{DT},n}^{t}}+\frac{q}{y_{n}^{t}}+\frac{a_{\text{UT},n}^{t}}{b_{n}^{t}c_{\text{UT},n}^{t}},~{}~{}~{}\forall n,t.\end{split} (5)

Due to some physical limitations, e.g., low computation capability and unstable communication, some clients may incur huge training latency in one edge aggregation round. Therefore, the deadline-based FL [31, 32, 33] is more realistic to deal with straggler clients. Specifically, ESs drop the clients whose the local model updates cannot be received before the deadline τdead,msubscript𝜏dead𝑚\tau_{\text{dead},m} (i.e., client n𝑛n such that τnt>τdead,msubscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡𝑛subscript𝜏dead𝑚\tau^{t}_{n}>\tau_{\text{dead},m}). In this paper, we consider deadline-based HFL. Therefore, the edge aggregation can be reformulated:

𝒘mt={1∑n∈𝒔mtXnt​∑n∈𝒔mtXnt​𝒘nt,if​∑n∈𝒔mtXnt≥Z1Z​∑τnt≤τZ𝒘nt,elsesubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑚cases1subscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑡𝑛subscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑡ifsubscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑡𝑛𝑍1𝑍subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡𝑛superscript𝜏𝑍superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑡else\bm{w}^{t}_{m}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{1}{\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X^{t}_{n}}\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X^{t}_{n}\bm{w}_{n}^{t},&\text{if}~{}\sum_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X^{t}_{n}\geq Z\\ \frac{1}{Z}\sum\nolimits_{\tau^{t}_{n}\leq\tau^{Z}}\bm{w}_{n}^{t},&\text{else}\end{array}\right. (6)

where Xntsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑡X_{n}^{t} is a binary random variable representing whether client n𝑛n’s model update can be received before the deadline (i.e., if τnt≤τdead,msubscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑡𝑛subscript𝜏dead𝑚\tau^{t}_{n}\leq\tau_{\text{dead},m}, Xnt=1superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑡1X_{n}^{t}=1; otherwise, Xnt=0superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑡0X_{n}^{t}=0), and τZsuperscript𝜏𝑍\tau^{Z} is the training time of the Z𝑍Z-th fastest client. In order to guarantee a minimum level of training performance, we require that at least Z𝑍Z local model updates must be used for edge aggregation. Therefore, in case less than Z𝑍Z clients’ updates are received before the deadline, the system has to wait for some additional time τZ−τdead,msuperscript𝜏𝑍subscript𝜏dead𝑚\tau^{Z}-\tau_{\text{dead},m}. For practical values of τZ−τdead,msuperscript𝜏𝑍subscript𝜏dead𝑚\tau^{Z}-\tau_{\text{dead},m}, the probability of having less than Z𝑍Z client updates received before the deadline is small. For analysis convenience, we assume that at least Z𝑍Z client updates can be received before the deadline in every edge aggregation round. In addition, we assume that the deadline of all ESs are set the same, τdead,m=τdead,∀msubscript𝜏dead𝑚subscript𝜏deadfor-all𝑚\tau_{\text{dead},m}=\tau_{\text{dead}},\forall m. The extension to heterogeneous deadlines is straightforward.

III-D Utility Function of Client Selection of HFL

Some existing HFL studies [15, 16, 34] have demonstrated that the convergence speed depends on the number of participating clients in each edge aggregation round for both strongly convex and non-convex HFL (i.e., the more clients participated, the faster convergence speed). In order to support the theoretical results, we show the training performance on our simulated HFL network with M=3𝑀3M=3 and N=50𝑁50N=50 in Fig. 2, and it is observed that more participating clients on ESs can improve the performance in both the strongly convex and non-convex HFL settings.

For now, we consider strongly strongly convex HFL, where the convergence speed is linearly dependent on the number of participating clients. The client selection policy for non-convex HFL will be developed in Section V. As in [31, 32, 33], not all the selected clients in 𝒔mtsubscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚\bm{s}^{t}_{m} may reach the EC stage (i.e., ∑n∈𝒔mtXnt≤Smtsubscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑡𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑡𝑚\sum_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X^{t}_{n}\leq S^{t}_{m}) due to straggler drop-out. To achieve a targeted convergence criteria, NO thus needs to run more FL rounds, thereby incurring a higher training cost. Therefore, it is necessary to develop an efficient client selection policy to improve the convergence speed for HFL, where more clients can participate in every round without dropping out. Let 𝑿mt={Xn,mt}∀n∈𝒩mtsubscriptsuperscript𝑿𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡for-all𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\bm{X}^{t}_{m}=\{X_{n,m}^{t}\}_{\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}}, then the utility of the client selection decision on ES m𝑚m is defined as:

μ​(𝒔mt;𝑿mt)=∑n∈𝒔mtXn,mt,𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑿𝑡𝑚subscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡\mu(\bm{s}^{t}_{m};\bm{X}^{t}_{m})=\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X_{n,m}^{t}, (7)

Further, let 𝒔t={𝒔1t,𝒔2t,…,𝒔Mt}superscript𝒔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒔1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒔2𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑀𝑡\bm{s}^{t}=\{\bm{s}_{1}^{t},\bm{s}_{2}^{t},\dots,\bm{s}_{M}^{t}\} denote the client selection decision of the overall system and 𝑿t={𝑿1t,𝑿2t,…,𝑿Mt}superscript𝑿𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑿1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑿2𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑿𝑀𝑡\bm{X}^{t}=\{\bm{X}_{1}^{t},\bm{X}_{2}^{t},\dots,\bm{X}_{M}^{t}\}. Therefore, the utility function of the whole HFL network is defined as:

μ​(𝒔t;𝑿t)=1M​∑n∈ℳ∑n∈𝒔mtXn,mt𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡1𝑀subscript𝑛ℳsubscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t})=\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{n\in\mathcal{M}}\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X_{n,m}^{t} (8)

III-E Client Selection Problem Formulation

The client selection problem for NO is a sequential decision-making problem. The goal of NO is to make selection decision 𝒔t,∀tsuperscript𝒔𝑡for-all𝑡\bm{s}^{t},\forall t to maximize the cumulative utility for a total of T𝑇T aggregation rounds. If an ES selects very few clients, its training performance may be degraded and the computation resources of computation resources of ESs may be wasted. To avoid bottleneck of HFL, we consider that NO equally divides the budget among the ESs (i.e., for each m𝑚m, its budget is B=B~/M𝐵~𝐵𝑀B=\tilde{B}/M). Assuming that NO knows a priori whether a selected client can return its model updates to the corresponding edge server in time, namely 𝑿t,∀tsuperscript𝑿𝑡for-all𝑡\bm{X}^{t},\forall t, then the client selection problem is formulated:

P1: max{𝒔t}t=1T​∑t=1Tμ​(𝒔t;𝑿t)subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}\max\nolimits_{\{\bm{s}^{t}\}_{t=1}^{T}}~{}~{}~{}\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t}) (9a)
s.t.∑n∈𝒔mtcn​(ynt)≤B,∀m∈ℳformulae-sequences.t.subscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡subscript𝑐𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑡𝑛𝐵for-all𝑚ℳ\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}\text{s.t.}~{}~{}~{}~{}\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}_{m}^{t}}c_{n}(y^{t}_{n})\leq B,~{}~{}\forall m\in\mathcal{M} (9b)
𝒔mt⊆𝒩mt,∀m,tsubscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡for-all𝑚𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\bm{s}^{t}_{m}\subseteq\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t},~{}~{}\forall m,t (9c)
𝒔mt∩𝒔m′t=∅,m,m′∈ℳ,∀t.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑚′𝑚superscript𝑚′ℳfor-all𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\bm{s}^{t}_{m}\cap\bm{s}^{t}_{m^{\prime}}=\emptyset,~{}~{}m,m^{\prime}\in\mathcal{M},\forall t. (9d)

The following challenges should be addressed to solve the client selection problem in HFL networks: (i) For maximizing the expected training utility of HFL, it is necessary to precisely estimate the selected clients in each edge aggregation round. In addition, since NO does not have enough experience to determine the selected clients at the first several rounds (i.e., cold start), collecting the historical data for estimation is important for this policy. (ii) With the successful participated clients estimation, how to optimize the selection decision on each ES under the limited budget should be carefully considered, because high variance of number of participated clients on each ES degrades the training performance. Therefore, we equally separate the total budget to each ES (constraint (9b)). (iii) Due to the movement of each client, the available connecting ESs can be considered as time-varying (constraint (9c)), which brings more difficulties to make an efficient client selection decision. Note that constraint (9d) can guarantee that each client only can be selected to communicate at most one ES. (iv) Since the selection decisions are based on the estimated participated clients 𝑿^tsuperscript^𝑿𝑡\hat{\bm{X}}^{t}, the accuracy of participated clients estimation will directly influence the training utility of NO. The following section will propose an policy based on the Multi-Armed Bandits (MAB) to address the mentioned challenges.

IV Context-Aware Online Client Selection policy for Strongly Convex HFL

In this section, we formulate our client selection problem of HFL as a Contextual Combinatorial Multi-Armed Bandit (CC-MAB). The combinatorial property is because NO pays computation resources from multiple clients for maximizing the training utility. The contextual property is because NO leverages contexts associated with clients to infer their participated probabilities. In this paper, whether successfully participating in the corresponding ES depends on many side factors, which are collaboratively referred to as context. We use contextual information to help infer the number of participated clients.

In CC-MAB, NO observes the context of clients at the beginning of each edge aggregation round before making the client selection decision. Recall that the participated probability of a client-ES pair depends on rDTt,yntsuperscriptsubscript𝑟DT𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡r_{\text{DT}}^{t},y_{n}^{t} and rUTtsuperscriptsubscript𝑟UT𝑡r_{\text{UT}}^{t} in Eq. (5). Although it is difficult, if not impossible, for ESs to know the channel state of clients, the ESs can easily capture their own channel state to connected clients [35, 36]. Based on the channel state of DT and bandwidth bntsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n}^{t}, ESs can compute the DT rate rDTtsuperscriptsubscript𝑟DT𝑡r_{\text{DT}}^{t} . In addition, since the movement speed of clients is much slower than the transmission speed of wireless signals, while NO cannot know the UT rate rUTtsuperscriptsubscript𝑟UT𝑡r_{\text{UT}}^{t}, it is not difficult to be inferred by rDTtsuperscriptsubscript𝑟DT𝑡r_{\text{DT}}^{t} (suppose that clients do not locate in the same area in each edge aggregation round). Note that computation resources yntsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡y_{n}^{t} of any client n𝑛n are revealed at the beginning of each round. Therefore, we set rDTtsuperscriptsubscript𝑟DT𝑡r_{\text{DT}}^{t} and yntsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑡y_{n}^{t} as context and use these information to help infer the participated probabilities. Let ϕn,mt∈Φsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡Φ\phi_{n,m}^{t}\in\Phi denote the context of client-ES pair (n,m)𝑛𝑚(n,m) in edge aggregation round t𝑡t. Without loss of generality, we normalize ϕn,mtsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡\phi_{n,m}^{t} in a bounded space Φ=[0,1]2Φsuperscript012\Phi=[0,1]^{2} using min-max feature scaling. Let ϕ={ϕn,mt}∀m,n∈𝒩mtbold-italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡for-all𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\bm{\phi}=\{\phi_{n,m}^{t}\}_{\forall m,n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}} denote the context of all clients on ESs. The context of all clients on ESs are collected in ϕt={ϕn,mt}∀m,n∈𝒩mtsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡for-all𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\bm{\phi}^{t}=\{\phi_{n,m}^{t}\}_{\forall m,n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}}. Whether successful participation of client n𝑛n on ES m𝑚m is a random variable parameterized by the context ϕn,mtsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡\phi_{n,m}^{t}. We slightly simplify the notation of selected clients and define the context-aware Xn,mt​(ϕn,mt)superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡X_{n,m}^{t}(\phi_{n,m}^{t}). Specifically, Xn,msubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚X_{n,m} is a mapping function for each client-ES pair (n,m)𝑛𝑚(n,m), since the training time of clients is usually location-dependent, e.g., the distance between the client and ES, the communication environment, and other processing tasks on a client. We further define pn,m​(ϕn,mt)≜𝔼​[Xn,m​(ϕn,mt)]≜subscript𝑝𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑋𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡p_{n,m}(\phi_{n,m}^{t})\triangleq\mathbb{E}[X_{n,m}(\phi_{n,m}^{t})] as the expected value (i.e., the participated probability Xn,mt∼Bernoulli​(pn,mt)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡Bernoullisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡X_{n,m}^{t}\sim\text{Bernoulli}(p_{n,m}^{t})) of Xn,m​(ϕn,mt)subscript𝑋𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡X_{n,m}(\phi_{n,m}^{t}).

IV-A Oracle Solution and Regret

Similar to the existing CC-MAB studies [17, 18, 19], before providing our policy design, we first give an Oracle benchmark solution to the client selection problem of HFL by assuming that the NO knows the context-aware successful participated probability pn,mt​(ϕn,mt)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡p_{n,m}^{t}(\phi_{n,m}^{t}), ∀m,n∈𝒩mtfor-all𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\forall m,n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}. In this ideal setting, the utility function μ​(𝒔t;𝒑t)𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{p}^{t}) is perfectly known by NO, and thus we can get the optimal value of the client selection problem. The long-term selection problem P1 can be decomposed into T𝑇T independent subproblems in each round:

P2: max𝒔t⁡μ​(𝒔t;𝒑t)subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\max\nolimits_{\bm{s}^{t}}~{}~{}~{}\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{p}^{t}) (10a)
s.t.∑n∈𝒔mtcn​(ynt)≤B,∀m∈ℳformulae-sequences.t.subscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡subscript𝑐𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑡𝑛𝐵for-all𝑚ℳ\displaystyle~{}\text{s.t.}~{}~{}~{}~{}\sum\nolimits_{n\in\bm{s}_{m}^{t}}c_{n}(y^{t}_{n})\leq B,~{}~{}\forall m\in\mathcal{M} (10b)
𝒔mt⊆𝒩mt,∀m,tsubscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡for-all𝑚𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\bm{s}^{t}_{m}\subseteq\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t},~{}~{}\forall m,t (10c)
𝒔mt∩𝒔m′t=∅,m,m′∈ℳ,∀t.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑚′𝑚superscript𝑚′ℳfor-all𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\bm{s}^{t}_{m}\cap\bm{s}^{t}_{m^{\prime}}=\emptyset,~{}~{}m,m^{\prime}\in\mathcal{M},\forall t. (10d)

P2 is a combinatorial optimization problem with M𝑀M Knapsack and a Matroid constraints. The combinatorial property is because NO should choose a proper client selection decision to optimize participated probabilities on all ESs in order to achieve higher convergence speed. Knapsack constraints are from the constraint (10b), which bounds computation resources payment on each ES.

To prove that (10c) is a matroid constraint, we firstly state the definition of matroid. A matroid ℰ=((X),(I))ℰ𝑋𝐼\mathcal{E}=(\mathcal{(}X),\mathcal{(}I)) is a system with independents sets, in which 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} is a finite set (named the ground set) and ℐℐ\mathcal{I} represents the set of independent subsets of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. It has the three following properties: (1) ∅∈ℐℐ\emptyset\in\mathcal{I} and 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} has at least one subset of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}; (2) For each A⊂B⊂𝒳𝐴𝐵𝒳A\subset B\subset\mathcal{X}, if A∈ℐ𝐴ℐA\in\mathcal{I}, then B∈ℐ𝐵ℐB\in\mathcal{I}; (3) If A,B∈ℐ𝐴𝐵ℐA,B\in\mathcal{I}, and |A|<|B|𝐴𝐵|A|<|B|, then ∃∈B∖A𝐵𝐴\exists\in B\setminus A such that A​{x}∈ℐ𝐴𝑥ℐA\{x\}\in\mathcal{I}.

In the subproblem P2, let 𝒳=∪m∈ℳ𝒩mt𝒳subscript𝑚ℳsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\mathcal{X}=\cup_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t} denote the ground set of matroid ℰ=(𝒳,ℐ)ℰ𝒳ℐ\mathcal{E}=(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{I}), and ℐ={I1,I2,…}ℐsubscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2…\mathcal{I}=\{I_{1},I_{2},\dots\} consists of subsets of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} (i.e., I1⊆𝒳subscript𝐼1𝒳I_{1}\subseteq\mathcal{X}, I2⊆𝒳subscript𝐼2𝒳I_{2}\subseteq\mathcal{X}, ……\dots), where all I∈ℐ𝐼ℐI\in\mathcal{I} includes at most one client from 𝒩mtsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t} for each m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M}. We can write I𝐼I as I=∪m∈ℳ𝒔mt𝐼subscript𝑚ℳsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡I=\cup_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\bm{s}_{m}^{t}, s.t. 𝒔mt∈𝒩mtsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\bm{s}_{m}^{t}\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}, ∀mfor-all𝑚\forall m. In this paper, ℐℐ\mathcal{I} is the set of all feasible client selection decisions. Therefore, it can be verified that Eq. (10c) is a matroid constraint [19, 37].

Based on our analysis, it is easy to observe that P2 is NP-hard, and hence it can be solved by brute-force, if the size of the HFL network is moderate. If the HFL network is too large, NO can use some commercial software to obtain the optimal solution, e.g., CPLEX [38]. For simplicity, we define the optimal Oracle solution for each P2 in edge aggregation round t𝑡t is 𝒔opt,tsuperscript𝒔opt𝑡\bm{s}^{\text{opt},t}. However, in practice, the prior knowledge of participated clients is infeasible, and thus the NO has to make a selection decision 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} based on the estimated participated clients 𝑿^tsuperscript^𝑿𝑡\hat{\bm{X}}^{t} in each edge aggregation round. Intuitively, NO should design an online client selection policy to choose 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} based on the estimation 𝑿^tsuperscript^𝑿𝑡\hat{\bm{X}}^{t}. The performance of an online client selection policy is calculated by utility loss compared with the Oracle solution, called regret. Suppose that we have a selection sequence {𝒔1,𝒔2,…,𝒔T}superscript𝒔1superscript𝒔2…superscript𝒔𝑇\{\bm{s}^{1},\bm{s}^{2},\dots,\bm{s}^{T}\} given by a policy, the expected regret is:

𝔼​[R​(T)]=∑t=1T(𝔼​[μ​(𝒔opt,t;𝑿t)]−𝔼​[μ​(𝒔t;𝑿t)]).𝔼delimited-[]𝑅𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼delimited-[]𝜇superscript𝒔opt𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡\mathbb{E}[R(T)]=\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}(\mathbb{E}[\mu(\bm{s}^{\text{opt},t};\bm{X}^{t})]-\mathbb{E}[\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t})]). (11)

The expectation is concerning with respect to the decisions made by the client selection decision policy and the participated clients over contexts.

IV-B Context-aware Online Client Selection Policy

Now, we will present our online client selection decision policy name Context-aware Online Client Selection (COCS). The COCS policy is designed based on CC-MAB. In edge aggregation round t𝑡t, the process of COCS of NO is operated sequentially as follows: (i) NO observes the contexts of all client-ES pairs ϕt={ϕn,mt}n,m∈𝒩mtsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\bm{\phi}^{t}=\{\phi_{n,m}^{t}\}_{n,m\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}}, ϕn,mt∈Φsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡Φ\phi_{n,m}^{t}\in\Phi. (ii) NO determines its selection decision 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} based on the observed context information ϕtsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡\bm{\phi}^{t} in the current round t𝑡t and the knowledge learned from the previous t−1𝑡1t-1 rounds. (iii) The selection decision 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} is applied. If snt≠0superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑡0s_{n}^{t}\neq 0, ∀n∈𝒔mtfor-all𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡\forall n\in\bm{s}_{m}^{t}, the clients located in the coverage area of ES m𝑚m can be selected by ES m𝑚m for training in round t𝑡t. (iv) At the end of each edge aggregation round, the local model updates ΔntsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑛𝑡\Delta_{n}^{t} from which clients are observed by all ESs, which is then used to update the estimated participated clients X^n,m​(ϕn,mt)subscript^𝑋𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡\hat{X}_{n,m}(\phi_{n,m}^{t}) from the observed context ϕn,mtsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡\phi_{n,m}^{t} of client-ES pair (n,m)𝑛𝑚(n,m).

The pseudocode of COCS policy is presented in Algorithm 1. It has two parameters K​(t)𝐾𝑡K(t) and hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T} to be designed, where K​(t)𝐾𝑡K(t) is a deterministic and monotonically increasing function used to identify the under-explored context, and hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T} decides how we partition the context space. The COCS policy is stated as follows:

Initialization Phase: Given parameter hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T}, the proposed policy first creates a partition denoted by ℒTsubscriptℒ𝑇\mathcal{L}_{T} for the context space Φ=[0,1]2Φsuperscript012\Phi=[0,1]^{2}, which splits ΦΦ\Phi into (hT)2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑇2(h_{T})^{2} sets. Each set is a 222-dimensional hypercube with size 1hT×⋯×1hT1subscriptℎ𝑇⋯1subscriptℎ𝑇\frac{1}{h_{T}}\times\cdots\times\frac{1}{h_{T}}. Note that hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T} is an important input parameter to guarantee policy performance. For each hypercube l∈ℒT𝑙subscriptℒ𝑇l\in\mathcal{L}_{T}, the NO keeps a counter Cn,mt​(l)subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑛𝑚𝑙C^{t}_{n,m}(l) for each client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N} and each ES m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M}. For the tuple (n,m,l)𝑛𝑚𝑙(n,m,l) of a counter Cn,mt​(l)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙C_{n,m}^{t}(l), we define a selection event Vn,m,lsubscript𝑉𝑛𝑚𝑙V_{n,m,l} that represents a selection decision satisfying the three following conditions: 1) the client n∈𝒩mt𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t} is selected to an ES m𝑚m; 2) the ES m𝑚m successfully receives the client n𝑛n before τdeadsubscript𝜏dead\tau_{\text{dead}} (i.e., τnt≤τdeadsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑡subscript𝜏dead\tau_{n}^{t}\leq\tau_{\text{dead}}); 3) the context of client-ES pair (n,m)𝑛𝑚(n,m) belongs to l𝑙l (i.e., ϕn,mt∈lsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙\phi_{n,m}^{t}\in l). The counter Cn,mt​(l)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙C_{n,m}^{t}(l) stores the number of times that the event Vn,m,lsubscript𝑉𝑛𝑚𝑙V_{n,m,l} occurs until edge aggregation round t𝑡t. Each ES m𝑚m also saves an experience ℰn,mt​(l)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙\mathcal{E}_{n,m}^{t}(l) for each client n𝑛n and each hypercube l𝑙l, which contains the observed participation indicators when a selection event Vn,m,lsubscript𝑉𝑛𝑚𝑙V_{n,m,l} occurs. Based on the observed participation indicators in ℰn,mt​(l)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙\mathcal{E}_{n,m}^{t}(l), the estimated participated probability for a selection event Vn,m,lsubscript𝑉𝑛𝑚𝑙V_{n,m,l} is computed by:

p^n,mt​(l)=1Cn,mt​(l)​∑X∈ℰn,mt​(l)X.superscriptsubscript^𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙subscript𝑋superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙𝑋\hat{p}_{n,m}^{t}(l)=\frac{1}{C_{n,m}^{t}(l)}\sum\nolimits_{X\in\mathcal{E}_{n,m}^{t}(l)}X. (12)

In each edge aggregation round t𝑡t, the COCS policy has the following phases:

Hypercube Identification Phase: If the local model updates ΔntsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑛𝑡\Delta_{n}^{t} of client n∈𝒩mt𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t} can be successfully received by an ES m𝑚m in edge aggregation round t𝑡t, we obtain that ln,mtsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑛𝑚𝑡l_{n,m}^{t} is the hypercube for the context ϕn,mtsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡\phi_{n,m}^{t}, the estimated participated probability of client n𝑛n on ES m𝑚m is X^n,mt=p^n,mt​(ln,mt)superscriptsubscript^𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑛𝑚𝑡\hat{X}_{n,m}^{t}=\hat{p}_{n,m}^{t}(l_{n,m}^{t}). Let 𝑿^t={X^n,mt}∀m,n∈𝒩mtsuperscript^𝑿𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡for-all𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡\hat{\bm{X}}^{t}=\{\hat{X}_{n,m}^{t}\}_{\forall m,n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}} denote the collection of all the estimated participated probabilities. For making a client selection decision, COCS policy needs to check whether these hypercubes have been explored sufficiently in order to ensure the enough accuracy of the estimated participated probability for each client-ES pair (n,m)𝑛𝑚(n,m). Therefore, we define under-explored hypercubes ℒmue​(ϕt)superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑚uesuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡\mathcal{L}_{m}^{\text{ue}}(\bm{\phi}^{t}) for the ES m𝑚m in edge aggregation round t𝑡t as follows:

ℒmue,t≜{l∈ℒT|∃ϕn,mt∈ϕt,ϕn,mt∈l,τnt≤τdeadand​Cn,mt​(l)≤K​(t)}.≜subscriptsuperscriptℒue𝑡𝑚conditional-set𝑙subscriptℒ𝑇missing-subexpressionformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑡subscript𝜏deadmissing-subexpressionandsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙𝐾𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\text{ue},t}_{m}\triangleq\left\{l\in\mathcal{L}_{T}\bigg{|}\begin{aligned} &~{}\exists\phi_{n,m}^{t}\in\bm{\phi}^{t},\phi_{n,m}^{t}\in l,\tau_{n}^{t}\leq\tau_{\text{dead}}\\ &~{}\text{and}~{}C_{n,m}^{t}(l)\leq K(t)\end{aligned}\right\}. (13)

Also, let 𝒩mue,t​(ϕt)≜{n∈𝒩mt|ln,mt∈ℒmue,t​(ϕt)}≜subscriptsuperscript𝒩ue𝑡𝑚superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡conditional-set𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑚ue𝑡superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡\mathcal{N}^{\text{ue},t}_{m}(\bm{\phi}^{t})\triangleq\{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}|l_{n,m}^{t}\in\mathcal{L}_{m}^{\text{ue},t}(\bm{\phi}^{t})\} denote the collection of the under-explored client n𝑛n for each ES m𝑚m. The challenge of COCS policy is how to decide the current estimated participated clients are accurate enough to guide the client selection decision in each edge aggregation round, which is referred as exploitation or more training results need to be collected for a certain hypercube, which is referred to as exploration. COCS policy aims to balance the exploration and exploitation phases in order to maximize the utility of NO up to a finite round T𝑇T. Based on the 𝒩mue,t​(ϕ)tsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚ue𝑡superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡\mathcal{N}_{m}^{\text{ue},t}(\bm{\phi})^{t}, COCS can identify that then either enters an exploration phase or an exploitation phase.

Exploration Phase: Firstly, let 𝒩mue,t​(ϕt)≜{n∈𝒩mt|𝒩mue,t≠∅}≜superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚ue𝑡superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡conditional-set𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚ue𝑡\mathcal{N}_{m}^{\text{ue},t}(\bm{\phi}^{t})\triangleq\{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}^{t}|\mathcal{N}_{m}^{\text{ue},t}\neq\emptyset\} denote an ES m𝑚m has under-explored clients, and 𝒩med,t​(ϕt)≜𝒩∖𝒩ue,t​(ϕt)≜superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚ed𝑡superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡𝒩superscript𝒩ue𝑡superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡\mathcal{N}_{m}^{\text{ed},t}(\bm{\phi}^{t})\triangleq\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{N}^{\text{ue},t}(\bm{\phi}^{t}) denote the ES m𝑚m does not have under-explored clients. If the ES m𝑚m has a non-empty 𝒩mue,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚ue𝑡\mathcal{N}_{m}^{\text{ue},t}, then COCS enters the exploration phase. We may have two following cases in exploration phase:

(i) All the clients have under-explored ESs. Intuitively, NO hopes to receive more local training updates ΔntsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑛𝑡\Delta_{n}^{t}. Therefore, COCS policy aims to select as many clients that have under-explored ESs sequentially solved by the following optimization:

Exploitation Phase: If the set of under-explored clients is empty (i.e., 𝒩mue,t=∅,∀msuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚ue𝑡for-all𝑚\mathcal{N}_{m}^{\text{ue},t}=\emptyset,\forall m), then COCS policy enters the exploitation phase. The optimal client selection decision 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} is derived by solving P2 from the current estimated participated clients 𝑿^tsuperscript^𝑿𝑡\hat{\bm{X}}^{t}:

Update Phase: After selecting the client-ES pair in each round t𝑡t, the proposed COCS policy observes whether the local model updates of selected clients can be received before the deadline τdeadsuperscript𝜏dead\tau^{\text{dead}}; then, it updates p^n,mt​(l)superscriptsubscript^𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑙\hat{p}_{n,m}^{t}(l) and Cn,mt​(l)subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑛𝑚𝑙C^{t}_{n,m}(l) of each hypercube l∈ℒT𝑙subscriptℒ𝑇l\in\mathcal{L}_{T}.

IV-C Performance Analysis

To present an upper performance bound of the COCS policy in terms of regret, we make the following assumption that the participated clients are similar are similar when their contexts are similar. This natural assumption is formalized by the following Hölder condition [17, 18, 19], which is defined as follows:

Assumption 1.

(Hölder Condition). If a real function f𝑓f on D𝐷D-dimensional Euclidean space satisfies Hödel condition, there exists L>0𝐿0L>0, α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 such that for any ϕ,ϕ′∈Φitalic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕ′Φ\phi,\phi^{\prime}\in\Phi, it holds that |fn​(ϕ)−fn​(ϕ′)|≤L​‖ϕ−ϕ′‖αsubscript𝑓𝑛italic-ϕsubscript𝑓𝑛superscriptitalic-ϕ′𝐿superscriptnormitalic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕ′𝛼|f_{n}(\phi)-f_{n}(\phi^{\prime})|\leq L\|\phi-\phi^{\prime}\|^{\alpha} for an arbitrary client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, where ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| is the Euclidean norm.

By providing the design of the input parameters K​(t)𝐾𝑡K(t) and hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T}, we show that COCS policy achieves a sublinear R​(T)=O​(Tγ)𝑅𝑇𝑂superscript𝑇𝛾R(T)=O(T^{\gamma}) with γ<1𝛾1\gamma<1, which guarantees that COCS has an asymptotically optimal performance. This means that the online client selection decision made by COCS policy converges to the Oracle solution. Because any edge aggregation round is either in the exploration or exploitation phase, the regret can be divided into two parts R​(T)=Rexplore​(T)+Rexploit​(T)𝑅𝑇subscript𝑅explore𝑇subscript𝑅exploit𝑇R(T)=R_{\text{explore}}(T)+R_{\text{exploit}}(T), where Rexplore​(T)subscript𝑅explore𝑇R_{\text{explore}}(T) and Rexploit​(T)subscript𝑅exploit𝑇R_{\text{exploit}}(T) are the regrets due to exploration and exploitation phases, respectively. The total regret bound is achieved by separately bounding these two parts. Therefore, we present the following two lemmas for bounding exploration and exploitation regrets.

Lemma 1.

(Bound of 𝔼​[Rexplore​(T)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑅explore𝑇\mathbb{E}[R_{\text{explore}}(T)].) Given the input parameters K​(t)=tz​log⁡(t)𝐾𝑡superscript𝑡𝑧𝑡K(t)=t^{z}\log(t) and hT=⌈Tγ⌉subscriptℎ𝑇superscript𝑇𝛾h_{T}=\lceil T^{\gamma}\rceil, where 0<z<10𝑧10<z<1 and 0<γ<120𝛾120<\gamma<\frac{1}{2}, the regret 𝔼​[Eexplore​(T)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐸explore𝑇\mathbb{E}[E_{\text{explore}}(T)] is bounded by:

Lemma 1 shows that the order of Rexplore​(T)subscript𝑅explore𝑇R_{\text{explore}}(T) is determined by the control function K​(T)𝐾𝑇K(T) and the number of hypercubes (hT)Dsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑇𝐷(h_{T})^{D} in partition ℒTsubscriptℒ𝑇\mathcal{L}_{T}.

The dominant order of regret upper bound, which indicates the COCS policy in Theorem 2 is sublinear. In addition, the regret bound is valid for any total rounds T𝑇T, and it can be used to characterize the convergence speed of HFL.

IV-D Complexity Analysis

The space complexity of COCS policy is determined by the number of counters Cn,mt​(l)subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑛𝑚𝑙C^{t}_{n,m}(l) and experiences ℰn,mt​(l)subscriptsuperscriptℰ𝑡𝑛𝑚𝑙\mathcal{E}^{t}_{n,m}(l) maintained for hypercubes. Because the counter is an integer for each hypercube, the space complexity is determined by the number of hypercubes. The experience ℰn,mt​(l)subscriptsuperscriptℰ𝑡𝑛𝑚𝑙\mathcal{E}^{t}_{n,m}(l) is a set of observed successfully participating clients records up to round t𝑡t, which requires a higher memory. However, it is unnecessary to store all historical records, since most estimators can be updated recursively. Therefore, the NO only needs to keep the current participated clients estimation for a hypercube. If COCS is run with the parameters in Theorem 2, the number of hypercubes is (hT)2=⌈T13​α+2⌉2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑇2superscriptsuperscript𝑇13𝛼22(h_{T})^{2}=\lceil T^{\frac{1}{3\alpha+2}}\rceil^{2}, and thus the required space is sublinear in total rounds T𝑇T. This means that when T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty, COCS will require infinite memory. In the practical implementations, NO only needs to keep the counters and experiences of hypercubes to which at least one of the observed contexts occurs. Therefore, the practical space requirement of some counters and experiences is much smaller than the theoretical requirement.

V COCS for Non-convex HFL

In this section, we will discuss the solutions for the client selection problems for non-convex HFL, e.g., neural network. The convergence speed weakly depends on the number of participated clients in traditional FL [4, 39], i.e., O​(1|𝒔t|​T)𝑂1superscript𝒔𝑡𝑇O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{|\bm{s}^{t}|}T}). In HFL, the convergence speed has similar performance O​(11M​∑m∈ℳ|𝒔mt|​T)𝑂11𝑀subscript𝑚ℳsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡𝑇O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}|\bm{s}_{m}^{t}|T}}) [16, 15]. Based on the utility function of strongly convex HFL in Eq. (7), we define the non-convex HFL utility function as follows:

μnon​(𝒔t;𝑿t)=1M​∑m∈ℳ∑n∈𝒔mtXn,mt.subscript𝜇nonsuperscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡1𝑀subscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑚𝑡\mu_{\text{non}}(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t})=\sqrt{\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\sum_{n\in\bm{s}^{t}_{m}}X_{n,m}^{t}}. (19)

Therefore, the client selection problem of non-convex HFL in edge aggregation round t𝑡t is formulated as follows:

P3:​max𝒔t⁡μnon​(𝒔t;𝑿t)​s.t.​(10b), (10c).P3:subscriptsuperscript𝒔𝑡subscript𝜇nonsuperscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡s.t.(10b), (10c)\textbf{P3:}~{}\max_{\bm{s}^{t}}~{}~{}\mu_{\text{non}}(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t})~{}~{}~{}\text{s.t.}~{}\text{\eqref{Eq:singlebudget}, \eqref{Eq:singlematroid}}. (20)

The problem P3 is also a combinatorial optimization problem. While brute-force search can always find the optimal solution, the complexity can be high due to the non-linear property in Eq. (20). In order to address this problem, we aim to design an efficient polynomial runtime approximation algorithm to solve P3 in the next subsection. In addition, the performance guarantee of the approximation algorithm will be presented.

V-A Approximated Oracle Solutions

To solve the problem P3, We first show that P3 is a monotone submodular maximization problem with M𝑀M knapsack and a matroid constraints. Below gives the definition of the monotone submodular maximization [37]:

Definition 1.

(Monotone Submodular Maximization.) A set function F:2I→ℛ:𝐹→superscript2𝐼ℛF:2^{I}\to\mathcal{R} is monotone increasing if ∀A⊆B⊆Ifor-all𝐴𝐵𝐼\forall A\subseteq B\subseteq I, F​(A)≤F​(B)𝐹𝐴𝐹𝐵F(A)\leq F(B). In addition, the function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is submodular if ∀A⊆B⊆Ifor-all𝐴𝐵𝐼\forall A\subseteq B\subseteq I and e∈I∖B𝑒𝐼𝐵e\in I\setminus B, F​(A∪{e})−F​(A)≥F​(B∪{e})−F​(B)𝐹𝐴𝑒𝐹𝐴𝐹𝐵𝑒𝐹𝐵F(A\cup\{e\})-F(A)\geq F(B\cup\{e\})-F(B).

Theorem 3.

P3 is a monotone submodular maximization with MMM knapsack and a matroid constraints problem.

Proof. See Appendix D in the supplemental file.   □□\Box

To facilitate the solution of client selection for non-convex HFL in P3, approximation algorithms are efficiently obtained approximate solutions in polynomial runtime. Some existing studies are focusing on solving the submodular maximization with knapsack and matroid constraints [20, 40, 41], and they proposed the approximation guarantee to the optimal solution. In this paper, we use the Fast Lazy Greedy (FLGreedy) algorithm in [20] to achieve the approximated oracle solution with 1(1+ϵ)​(2+2​M)11italic-ϵ22𝑀\frac{1}{(1+\epsilon)(2+2M)}-approximation guarantee, where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is an error parameter of the algorithm.

For coherence, we do not introduce the detailed FLGreedy algorithm here. The FLGreedy algorithm acquires the client selection decision of the client sequentially, which starts with the all-n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙null decisions. In each edge aggregation round, it selects a client to an ES that gives the largest incremental learning utility. Because each client can only be selected at most one ES and each iteration decides the client selection decision for one client, the algorithm terminates in at most M𝑀M iterations. Based on the results for submodular maximization with a knapsack and a matroid constraints in [20], the FLGreedy algorithm guarantees to yield a 1(1+ϵ)​(2+2​M)11italic-ϵ22𝑀\frac{1}{(1+\epsilon)(2+2M)}-approximation for P3:

Lemma 3.

In an arbitrary edge aggregation round t𝑡t, let 𝐬∗,tsuperscript𝐬𝑡\bm{s}^{*,t} be the client selection decision solved by FLGreedy algorithm and 𝐬opt,tsuperscript𝐬opt𝑡\bm{s}^{\text{opt},t} be the optimal client selection decision for the problem P3, we will have μ​(𝐬∗,t;𝐗t)≥1(1+ϵ)​(2+2​M)​μ​(𝐬opt,t;𝐗t)𝜇superscript𝐬𝑡superscript𝐗𝑡11italic-ϵ22𝑀𝜇superscript𝐬opt𝑡superscript𝐗𝑡\mu(\bm{s}^{*,t};\bm{X}^{t})\geq\frac{1}{(1+\epsilon)(2+2M)}\mu(\bm{s}^{\text{opt},t};\bm{X}^{t}).

Proof. The proof follows [20] and hence is omitted.   □□\Box

We use FLGreedy to approximate the optimal client selection decision with oracle information on participated clients. Note that the actual performance of the FLGreedy algorithm is usually much better than the 1(1+ϵ)​(2+2​M)11italic-ϵ22𝑀\frac{1}{(1+\epsilon)(2+2M)} approximation ratio in practice.

V-B Performance Analysis for Non-Convex HFL

The regret in Eq. (11) is used when the optimal oracle solutions can be derivable. Because the FLGreedy algorithm can efficiently approximate the optimal oracle solution for P3 instead of obtaining the optimal oracle solution. As such, we leverage the definition of δ𝛿\delta-regret, which is usually used in MAB based on approximation algorithms [42]. For a δ𝛿\delta-approximation algorithm, i.e., the solution 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} solved by the approximation algorithm satisfies μ​(𝒔t;𝑿t)≥1δ​μ​(𝒔opt,t;𝑿t)𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡1𝛿𝜇superscript𝒔opt𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t})\geq\frac{1}{\delta}\mu(\bm{s}^{\text{opt},t};\bm{X}^{t}), for problem P3, the δ𝛿\delta-regret is defined as follows:

Rδ​(T)=∑t=1T1δ​μ​(𝒔opt,t;𝑿t)−∑t=1Tμ​(𝒔t;𝑿t).superscript𝑅𝛿𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇1𝛿𝜇superscript𝒔opt𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝜇superscript𝒔𝑡superscript𝑿𝑡R^{\delta}(T)=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{1}{\delta}\mu(\bm{s}^{\text{opt},t};\bm{X}^{t})-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mu(\bm{s}^{t};\bm{X}^{t}). (21)

Because the FLGreedy algorithm for the problem P3 has an approximation ratio of 1(1+ϵ)​(2+2​M)11italic-ϵ22𝑀\frac{1}{(1+\epsilon)(2+2M)}, COCS policy obtains δ=1(1+ϵ)​(2+2​M)𝛿11italic-ϵ22𝑀\delta=\frac{1}{(1+\epsilon)(2+2M)}. The definition of δ𝛿\delta-regret essentially compares the utility of a policy with the lower bound of the approximated oracle solution.

Next, we aim to present the input parameters K​(t)𝐾𝑡K(t) and hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T} and propose a regret upper bound for COCS policy. The regret analysis is also proved based on the Hölder condition in Assumption 1. Given the input parameters K​(t)𝐾𝑡K(t) and hTsubscriptℎ𝑇h_{T} in Theorem 4, we achieve a sublinear regret upper bound of COCS policy for P3 as follows:

Theorem 4.

(δ𝛿\delta-Regret Upper Bound.) If K​(t)=t2​α+23​α+2​log⁡(t)𝐾𝑡superscript𝑡2𝛼23𝛼2𝑡K(t)=t^{\frac{2\alpha+2}{3\alpha+2}}\log(t), hT=⌈T13​α+2⌉subscriptℎ𝑇superscript𝑇13𝛼2h_{T}=\lceil T^{\frac{1}{3\alpha+2}}\rceil, Hölder condition holds true and a δ𝛿\delta-approximation is applied for optimization, then the dominate order of δ𝛿\delta-regret 𝔼​[Rδ​(T)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑅𝛿𝑇\mathbb{E}[R^{\delta}(T)] is O​(4​N2​M​Bδ​cmin​T2​α+23​α+2​log⁡(T))𝑂4superscript𝑁2𝑀𝐵𝛿superscript𝑐minsuperscript𝑇2𝛼23𝛼2𝑇O\left(\frac{4N^{2}MB}{\delta c^{\text{min}}}T^{\frac{2\alpha+2}{3\alpha+2}}\log(T)\right).

Proof. See Appendix E in the supplemental file.  □□\Box

The regret upper bound given in Theorem 4 implies that COCS policy performs well enough if the subproblem in each edge aggregation round can only be derived approximately. A sublinear δ𝛿\delta-regret can be achieved based on the performance guarantee of δ𝛿\delta-approximation algorithms.

VI Simulations

In this section, we conduct simulations to evaluate the performance of our proposed COCS policy of HFL. Firstly, we introduce the simulation setup in this paper. Then, we move to evaluate the performance of strongly convex and non-convex HFL by different benchmarks respectively. The simulation results will show how our proposed COCS policy impacts the convergence and ML model performance.

VI-A Setup

Datasets and Training models: We set up the simulation with PyTorch and the computation is conducted by a high-performance workstation with 2 NVIDIA RTX 2080 GPUs. We have prepared two datasets for evaluating our proposed COCS algorithm. Specifically, MNIST dataset [43] under a logistic regression, which is widely used for strongly convex FL studies [3, 44]. For the non-convex HFL, we use CIFAR-10 dataset [45] by adopting a CNN with two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers (each with 646464 channels), followed with 2×2222\times 2 max polling, two fully-connected layers with 384 and 192 units, and finally a softmax output layer. For each simulation, we distribute the dataset among N=50𝑁50N=50 clients in a general non-iid fashion such that each clients only contains samples of only two labels.

Contexts: For the context generation, in each edge aggregation round, we assume the allocated bandwidth of all clients is sampling from a uniform distribution between 𝒰∼[0.3,1]similar-to𝒰0.31\mathcal{U}\sim[0.3,1]MHz for MNIST dataset and 𝒰∼[2,4]similar-to𝒰24\mathcal{U}\sim[2,4]MHz for CIFAR-10 dataset, since the data and model sizes are different for each dataset. Likewise, the available computation capacity of all clients is also sampling from 𝒰∼[2,4]similar-to𝒰24\mathcal{U}\sim[2,4]MHz for MNIST dataset and 𝒰∼[8,15]similar-to𝒰815\mathcal{U}\sim[8,15]MHz for CIFAR-10 dataset. The distance dn,mtsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑛𝑚𝑡d_{n,m}^{t} between client and ES is from 𝒰∼[0,2]similar-to𝒰02\mathcal{U}\sim[0,2]km.

Parameters of HFL Networks: In our simulated HFL network, the radius of each ES is 2km. Within the coverage area, there are several clients randomly distributed and communicated by the corresponding ES through a wireless channel in each edge aggregation round. In the edge aggregation round t𝑡t, the downlink and uplink channel gain are decomposed of both small-scale fading and large-scale fading, where the small-scale fading is set as Rayleigh distribution with uniform variance and the large-scale fading are calculated by the path-loss with random shadowing gDT,nt=gUT,nt=37.6​log⁡(dn,mt)+128.1superscriptsubscript𝑔DT𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔UT𝑛𝑡37.6superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑛𝑚𝑡128.1g_{\text{DT},n}^{t}=g_{\text{UT},n}^{t}=37.6\log(d_{n,m}^{t})+128.1, where d𝑑d represent the distance of client-ES pair (n,m)𝑛𝑚(n,m). To clearly show the performance difference of each benchmark, we set HFL network parameters for the two datasets shown in Table I.

VI-B Comparison Benchmarks

We compare the COCS policy with the four following benchmarks:

1) Oracle: the Oracle algorithm knows precisely whether one client can be received by the corresponding ES before the deadline τdeadsuperscript𝜏dead\tau^{\text{dead}} with any observed context. In each aggregation round, it makes a client selection decision to maximize the utility in Eq. (10a): brute-force for the strongly convex HFL and GreedyLS for non-convex HFL.

2) Combinatorial UCB (CUCB): CUCB is designed based on a classical MAB policy UCB [27]. It develops combinations of client selection decisions on all ESs to enumerate NO’s decision 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}. CUCB runs UCB with feasible NO selection decisions 𝒔𝒔\bm{s} and learns the expected utility for each 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} in edge aggregation round. Since CUCB does not fit for the time-varying arm set, we set the static computation and transmission resource for client-ES pairs.

3) LinUCB: LinUCB [46] is a contextual variant of running CUCB. LinUCB also aims to learn the expected utility for client selection decision 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}, which assumes that the utility of an arm is a linear function of client-ES pairs’ contexts.

4) Random: The Random algorithm selects a client to an accessible ES randomly in each edge aggregation round under these two constraints.

VI-C Performance Evaluation of Strongly Convex HFL

1) Comparison on cumulative utilities: Fig. 2 shows the cumulative utilities and regret obtained by the COCS policy and the other 4 benchmarks during 1,000 edge aggregation rounds under logistic regression on the MNIST dataset. For the cumulative utilities in Fig. 3, it is observed that Oracle achieves the highest cumulative utilities and provides an upper bound to the other benchmarks as expected. Among the others, COCS policy significantly outperforms the other benchmarks and has a closed cumulative utility performance to Oracle. The profit of the context of client-ES pairs can be shown by comparing the performance of context-aware policy (LinUCB) and context-unaware policies (CUCB and Random). Moreover, the results indicate that the cumulative utilities of CUCB are similar to the Random policy. The disadvantage of CUCB is from the following two reasons: (1) an arm of CUCB is a combination of the selection decisions of all client-ES pairs, and thus CUCB has a large number of arms. This means that CUCB is difficult to enter the exploitation phase. (2) CUCB fails to capture the connection between context and clients. The cumulative utilities of LinUCB are based on the context, for which a CUCB arm is not effective to produce a good result due to the large arm set. Fig. 3 notably depicts the regret generated by the 5 benchmarks. It is easy to observe that our proposed COCS policy incurs a sublinear regret.

2) Training performance and client selection results: We use two metrics to evaluate the training performance based on client selection policies: edge aggregation rounds to achieve targeted testing accuracy and final testing accuracy. In Fig. 4, we present the training performance under logistic regression on the MNIST dataset from different client selection benchmarks. Oracle policy, as expected, results in the fastest convergence speed and highest accuracy among all benchmarks. Although COCS performs slower than Oracle policy during the first several rounds due to exploration, it achieves similar testing accuracy to Oracle in 200th round. In particular, it easy to observe that COCS outperforms others. Due to the insufficient selection of clients all the rounds, Random selecting clients is considerably inferior to all other benchmarks. For clarifying the training performance, we present an auxiliary Table II to emphasize the results, in which the targeted accuracy on MNIST dataset is set 70%. As is shown, our proposed COCS policy only uses 121 rounds to achieve 70% test accuracy, which is 36, 13 and 40 rounds faster than CUCB, LinUCB and Random.

In Fig. 4, we show the temporal number of clients are selected in each edge aggregation round. The upper bound and lower bound of clients are Oracle and Random policies. Although COCS, LinUCB, and CUCB all have increasing levels due to obtaining historical experiences, it is easy to observe that the increase of CUCB is very slow, and COCS outperforms the other two benchmarks. The reason why the number of successful participated clients are few in the first several rounds via COCS is that most of selected clients cannot be received by ESs before deadline τdeadsuperscript𝜏dead\tau^{\text{dead}}. The results match the accumulative utilities and regret in Fig. 2.

3) Impact of budget B𝐵B: Fig. 4 shows that the training performance of COCS under different budgets B𝐵B (B=3.5,5𝐵3.55B=3.5,5 and 101010). It is easy to observe that COCS has better performance when NO increases the budget B𝐵B. This is simply to explain because increasing the budget can select more clients in each round in order to increase the utility of HFL. In particular, when B=5𝐵5B=5 NO only uses 77 rounds to achieve 70% test accuracy, which is much faster than B=3.5𝐵3.5B=3.5. However, the training performance does not have significant improvement from B=5𝐵5B=5 to 101010. Fig. 4 presents the cumulative utilities of these five benchmarks after 200 edge aggregation rounds. Clearly, for all the benchmarks, the NO can achieve higher cumulative utilities with increasing budget. As can be observed, when the budget increases from 3.53.53.5 to 555, the benefit of client selection gradually increases. However, if the budget is set large, the redundant selection does not have significant improvement, which is similar to the results in Fig. 4. The reason may be because some client-ES pairs performing poor transmission rate cannot be successfully received by ESs before the deadline τdeadsuperscript𝜏dead\tau^{\text{dead}}, even if NO increases the rental computation resources.

4) Impact of deadline τdeadsuperscript𝜏dead\tau^{\text{dead}}: Fig. 4 depicts the training performance and 4 depicts the cumulative utilities under different deadlines τdead=2superscript𝜏dead2\tau^{\text{dead}}=2sec, 444sec and 888sec. Clearly, we can see that when NO increases the value of deadline, the number of clients increases gradually, which performs similarly to increasing budget B𝐵B. However, if NO sets the deadline too large (i.e., τdead=8superscript𝜏dead8\tau^{\text{dead}}=8sec), training performance and cumulative utilities perform similarly to τdead=4superscript𝜏dead4\tau^{\text{dead}}=4sec. More specifically, cumulative utilities of COCS only increase from 5,125 to 5,378. Moreover, the increasing level of different τdeadsuperscript𝜏dead\tau^{\text{dead}} is less than increasing budget B𝐵B, since the less budget can control the number of selected clients, which is more dominant than deadline for the training performance.

VI-D Performance Evaluation of Non-convex HFL

In this subsection, we aim to show the performance of non-convex HFL under the CNN model on the CIFAR-10 dataset, where the utility is quadratically related to the number of participated clients. We set the error parameter of FLGreedy algorithm ϵ=0.3italic-ϵ0.3\epsilon=0.3. The HFL network also includes 50 clients and 3 ESs, and the other parameters are introduced in Table I. Fig. 7 depicts the cumulative utilities during 1,880 edge aggregation rounds and Fig. 7 depicts regret. Similar to the performance of strongly convex HFL in Fig. 2, Oracle policy performs the best cumulative utilities as expected, and COCS outperforms the other 3 benchmarks, e.g., 1.7×\times higher than CUCB policy. In particular, the difference of cumulative utilities between Oracle and COCS is smaller than the result in Fig. 2a, since this is an approximated Oracle solution in this case. It is also observed that COCS achieves a sublinear regret in Fig. 7.

Fig. 7 shows the test accuracy of different client selection benchmarks on the CIFAR-10 dataset. Since the training model and data size of CIFAR-10 is complicated enough, training performance of different benchmarks are clear to see. Oracle policy has the best performance among all benchmarks, which achieves 68.41% test accuracy. In Table II, COCS policy can achieve 67.93% test accuracy, which is 4.17%, 1.74%, and 5.68% higher than LinUCB, CUCB, and Random policies. From the convergence performance perspective, COCS also outperforms the other three benchmarks. We can conclude that COCS policy can improve the training performance for HFL significantly both on strongly convex and non-convex settings.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we investigated the client selection problem to improve the training performance for HFL. An online decision-making policy, called Context-aware Online Client Selection (COCS), was designed for NO to make proper client selection decisions for each client-ES pair. COCS was developed based on the CC-MAB framework, where NO observes the context of client-ES pairs and learns the participated probabilities to select clients and guide rental computation resources. Our proposed COCS policy departs from conventional optimization-based algorithms, which is able to work in HFL networks with uncertain information. More specifically, COCS addresses many practical challenges for HFL networks, and it is easy to implement and achieves a provably asymptotically optimal performance guarantee. Although our COCS policy has presented superior performance in extensive HFL experiments, there are still several future research questions. For example, considering dynamic partition of context space may improve the selection results, since it can generate more appropriate hypercubes. A theoretical improvement of convergence speed from COCS should also be considered.

The proof is completed.  □□\Box

Appendix B Proof of Lemma 2

Based on the COCS policy, we know that if a client selection decision 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} enters in exploration phase (i.e., the event VStsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑆𝑡V_{S}^{t}), the rewards of NO is at least as high as the reward of clients which are selected in 𝒔˙tsuperscript˙𝒔𝑡\dot{\bm{s}}^{t}, i.e., μ​(G;𝑿^t)≥μ​(𝒔˙t;𝑿^t)𝜇𝐺superscript^𝑿𝑡𝜇superscript˙𝒔𝑡superscript^𝑿𝑡\mu(G;\hat{\bm{X}}^{t})\geq\mu(\dot{\bm{s}}^{t};\hat{\bm{X}}^{t}). If Eq. (45) is true, the three parts of E3subscript𝐸3E_{3} cannot be satisfied at the same time: combining E3.2subscript𝐸3.2E_{\text{3.2}} and E3.3subscript𝐸3.3E_{\text{3.3}} with Eq. (45) yields μ​(G;𝒑best,t)<μ​(𝒔˙t;𝒑worst,t)𝜇𝐺superscript𝒑best𝑡𝜇superscript˙𝒔𝑡superscript𝒑worst𝑡\mu(G;\bm{p}^{\text{best},t})<\mu(\dot{\bm{s}}^{t};\bm{p}^{\text{worst},t}), which contradicts the E3.1subscript𝐸3.1E_{\text{3.1}}. To sum up, under condition Eq. (43), the probability ℙ​{SGt,W​(t)}ℙsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝐺𝑡𝑊𝑡\mathbb{P}\{S_{G}^{t},W(t)\} can be bounded by:

Based on the above analysis, the regret for 𝔼​[Rs​(T)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑠𝑇\mathbb{E}[R_{s}(T)] can be bounded as follows:

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 1

Proof. Let K​(t)=tz​log⁡(t)𝐾𝑡superscript𝑡𝑧𝑡K(t)=t^{z}\log(t), 0<z<10𝑧10<z<1 and hT=⌈Tγ⌉subscriptℎ𝑇superscript𝑇𝛾h_{T}=\lceil T^{\gamma}\rceil, 0<γ<120𝛾120<\gamma<\frac{1}{2}, 0<γ<1D0𝛾1𝐷0<\gamma<\frac{1}{D}, H​(t)=N​M​Bcmin​t−z2𝐻𝑡𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐minsuperscript𝑡𝑧2H(t)=\frac{NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}t^{-\frac{z}{2}}, and the condition 2​H​(t)+2​N​M​Bcmin​L​2α2​T−γ​α≤A​tθ2𝐻𝑡2𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min𝐿superscript2𝛼2superscript𝑇𝛾𝛼𝐴superscript𝑡𝜃2H(t)+\frac{2NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}L2^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}T^{-\gamma\alpha}\leq At^{\theta} is satisfied for all t𝑡t. Combining Lemmas 1 and 2, the regret R​(T)𝑅𝑇R(T) can be bounded by:

𝔼​[R​(T)]=𝔼​[Rexplore​(T)]+𝔼​[Rexploit​(T)]≤N2​M​Bcmin​4​(Tz+2​γ​log⁡(T)+T2​γ)+N​M​Bcmin​(∑k=1B/cmin(Nk))​π23+3​N​M​Bcmin​L​2α2​T1−γ​α+A1+θ​T1+θ.𝔼delimited-[]𝑅𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑅explore𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑅exploit𝑇superscript𝑁2𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min4superscript𝑇𝑧2𝛾𝑇superscript𝑇2𝛾𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐minsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐵superscript𝑐minmatrix𝑁𝑘superscript𝜋233𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min𝐿superscript2𝛼2superscript𝑇1𝛾𝛼𝐴1𝜃superscript𝑇1𝜃\begin{split}\mathbb{E}[R(T)]&=\mathbb{E}[R_{\text{explore}}(T)]+\mathbb{E}[R_{\text{exploit}}(T)]\\ &\leq\frac{N^{2}MB}{c^{\text{min}}}4(T^{z+2\gamma}\log(T)+T^{2\gamma})\\ &+\frac{NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}\bigg{(}\sum_{k=1}^{B/c^{\text{min}}}\begin{pmatrix}N\\ k\end{pmatrix}\bigg{)}\frac{\pi^{2}}{3}\\ &+\frac{3NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}L2^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}T^{1-\gamma\alpha}+\frac{A}{1+\theta}T^{1+\theta}.\end{split} (56)

The summands contribute to the regret R​(T)𝑅𝑇R(T) due to the leading orders O​(log⁡(T)​Tz+2​γ)𝑂𝑇superscript𝑇𝑧2𝛾O(\log(T)T^{z+2\gamma}), O​(T1−γ​α)𝑂superscript𝑇1𝛾𝛼O(T^{1-\gamma\alpha}) and O​(T1+θ)𝑂superscript𝑇1𝜃O(T^{1+\theta}). By selecting the parameters z,γ,A𝑧𝛾𝐴z,\gamma,A and θ𝜃\theta as z=2​α3​α+2∈(0,1)𝑧2𝛼3𝛼201z=\frac{2\alpha}{3\alpha+2}\in(0,1), γ=z2​α𝛾𝑧2𝛼\gamma=\frac{z}{2\alpha}, θ=−z2𝜃𝑧2\theta=-\frac{z}{2}, and A=2​N​M​Bcmin+2​N​M​Bcmin​L​2α2𝐴2𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min2𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min𝐿superscript2𝛼2A=\frac{2NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}+\frac{2NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}L2^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}, we can balance the leading orders. Therefore, the regret R​(T)𝑅𝑇R(T) reduces to

𝔼​[R​(T)]≤4​N2​M​Bcmin​(log⁡(T)​T2​α+23​α+2+T23​α+2)+N​M​Bcmin​(∑k=1B/cmin(Nk))​π23+(3​N​M​Bcmin​L​2α2+2​N​M​Bcmin​1+L​2α2(2​α+2)/(3​α+2))​T2​α+23​α+2.𝔼delimited-[]𝑅𝑇4superscript𝑁2𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min𝑇superscript𝑇2𝛼23𝛼2superscript𝑇23𝛼2𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐minsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐵superscript𝑐minmatrix𝑁𝑘superscript𝜋233𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min𝐿superscript2𝛼22𝑁𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐min1𝐿superscript2𝛼22𝛼23𝛼2superscript𝑇2𝛼23𝛼2\begin{split}\mathbb{E}[R(T)]&\leq\frac{4N^{2}MB}{c^{\text{min}}}(\log(T)T^{\frac{2\alpha+2}{3\alpha+2}}+T^{\frac{2}{3\alpha+2}})\\ &+\frac{NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}\bigg{(}\sum_{k=1}^{B/c^{\text{min}}}\begin{pmatrix}N\\ k\end{pmatrix}\bigg{)}\frac{\pi^{2}}{3}\\ &+\bigg{(}\frac{3NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}L2^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}+\frac{2NMB}{c^{\text{min}}}\frac{1+L2^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}}{(2\alpha+2)/(3\alpha+2)}\bigg{)}T^{\frac{2\alpha+2}{3\alpha+2}}.\end{split} (57)

From the bound in Eq. (57), the dominant order is

O​(4​N2​M​Bcmin​T2​α+D3​α+D​log⁡(T)).𝑂4superscript𝑁2𝑀𝐵superscript𝑐minsuperscript𝑇2𝛼𝐷3𝛼𝐷𝑇O\bigg{(}\frac{4N^{2}MB}{c^{\text{min}}}T^{\frac{2\alpha+D}{3\alpha+D}}\log(T)\bigg{)}. (58)

The proof is completed.  □□\Box

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 3

Proof. Since we have presented knapsack and matroid constraints from (10b) and (10c) in Section IV-A, it only remains to show that P3 is monotone submodular maximization. It is easy to verify the monotone property, as square function is monotone increasing. Consider any sets A⊆B⊆𝒩×ℳ𝐴𝐵𝒩ℳA\subseteq B\subseteq\mathcal{N}\times\mathcal{M}, and the client-ES pair (n′,m′)∉Bsuperscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′𝐵(n^{\prime},m^{\prime})\notin B, then we have:

(1M​∑(n,m)∈A∪(n′,m′)pn,mt)12−(1M​∑(n,m)∈Apn,mt)12≈pn′,m′t2​(M​∑(n,m)∈Apn,mt)12≥pn′,m′t2​(M​∑(n,m)∈Bpn,mt)12≈(1M​∑(n,m)∈B∪(n′,m′)pn,mt)12−(1M​∑(n,m)∈Bpn,mt)12,superscript1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝐴superscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡12superscript1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝑝superscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′𝑡2superscript𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝑝superscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′𝑡2superscript𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡12superscript1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝐵superscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡12superscript1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑚𝑡12\begin{split}&\bigg{(}\frac{1}{M}\sum_{(n,m)\in A\cup(n^{\prime},m^{\prime})}p_{n,m}^{t}\bigg{)}^{\frac{1}{2}}-\bigg{(}\frac{1}{M}\sum_{(n,m)\in A}p_{n,m}^{t}\bigg{)}^{\frac{1}{2}}\\ &\approx\frac{p_{n^{\prime},m^{\prime}}^{t}}{2(M\sum_{(n,m)\in A}p_{n,m}^{t})^{\frac{1}{2}}}\geq\frac{p_{n^{\prime},m^{\prime}}^{t}}{2(M\sum_{(n,m)\in B}p_{n,m}^{t})^{\frac{1}{2}}}\\ &\approx\bigg{(}\frac{1}{M}\sum_{(n,m)\in B\cup(n^{\prime},m^{\prime})}p_{n,m}^{t}\bigg{)}^{\frac{1}{2}}-\bigg{(}\frac{1}{M}\sum_{(n,m)\in B}p_{n,m}^{t}\bigg{)}^{\frac{1}{2}},\end{split}

where the above proof is based on the first order Taylor expansion [48]. Therefore, the client selection decision of non-convex HFL in P3 is a submodular maximization. This concludes the proof.   □□\Box

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 4

Proof. The proof of Theorem 4 is similar to the proof of Theorem 2, and thus we only present a proof sketch of Theorem 4. The expected δ𝛿\delta-regret is also divided into two parts:

𝔼​[Rδ​(T)]=𝔼​[Rexploreδ​(T)]+𝔼​[Rexploitδ​(T)].𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑅𝛿𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝛿explore𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝛿exploit𝑇\mathbb{E}[R^{\delta}(T)]=\mathbb{E}[R^{\delta}_{\text{explore}}(T)]+\mathbb{E}[R^{\delta}_{\text{exploit}}(T)]. (59)
